page.title: 17FLOWERS IN BOWERCHALKE
page.content: The chalky soil of the Downland, improved only by sheep & cows grazing, gives a rich variety of wild flowers. In Spring, the Cowslips & Milkwort, blue, pink, white, are abundant, and followed by Fellwort, Dropwort, Hare- bells & Thyme. Where the Rockroses are plentiful the Brown Argus & 3 of the Blue Butterflies visit. Squinancywort & Salad Burnet bloom freely, side by side with the Dwarf Thistle, Knapweed, Wild Basil & Yellow Rattle. Meadow Saxifrage flowers on the top of Marley -combe. 5 species of Orchid can be found. Clustered Bellflower is espec- ially fine in August. The Autumn Gentian is not as common as the Cent- aury. Wild Roses proliferate with Scabious & Blue Vetches on verges. Broomrape parasitises Knapweed. Wild Pansy follows harvest, then Mushrooms. Nuts, Blackberries & Sloes abound.
